last_post.content: This sounds bad… is this bad? https://www.wsj.com/articles/twitter-offers-free-ads-to-brands-that-advertise-on-its-platform-11673654556

My winter break project was an app to browse and follow academics from many of the lists on the Academics on Mastodon page.

https://find.sciences.social reads data from the lists, and makes it easy to see profiles and follow academics.

The app doesn't scrape or store any information - it just shows the cdv-files in a new and (I hope) more useful way.

Give it a try.

All this stuff is connected to the 'tenfold way', a topic with many intricate aspects. I outline the basics here:

http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/tenfold.html

but there's a lot I still find mysterious. That's why I was rereading Milnor's book Morse Theory.

Okay, that's all for now!

(28/n, n = 28)

A 'compact symmetric space' is, a compact Riemannian manifold with enough symmetry that there's an isometry fixing each point and acting as -1 on its tangent space.

Cartan classified these things, and there's a nice table here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_space#Classification_result

Amazingly, there are 10 infinite series of compact symmetric spaces, with 8 arising from real Bott periodicity as sketched here, and the other 2 arising from complex Bott periodicity, which is much simpler:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bott_periodicity_theorem#Geometric_model_of_loop_spaces

(27/n)

The Sadie Collective, a nonprofit for Black women in quant and social science fields, is hosting their first in-person conference since 2020 from February 16 - 19, 2023.

Sponsor a student you know to go: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2023-sadie-tm-alexander-conference-for-economics-and-related-fields-tickets-445153565297?aff=Website.

title: Adding Interactive Visual Syntax to Textual Code

last_post.content:
Recent announcement of Project Mage inspired me to write a short tour around the current scene of #StructuralEditing - from my perspective, so I shall begin with the projects that resonate with me most strongly.

So, the number 1 is @leif 's work on "Interactive Visual Syntax", as explained here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8htgAxJuK5c

(Leif also implemented this idea in the visr.pl online IDE)

Number 2 is @vez 's Polytope editor for JavaScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8g_XCZSY7lM

I was also hugely impressed with @disconcision 's Fructure, which - except just being a beautiful user experience also is a beautiful implementation:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnbVCNIh1NA

Andy has since moved to other places, contributing to Cyrus Omar's hazel.org and David Moon's tylr.fun

Not long after releasing my first prototype of GRASP, I ran into Yasuyuki Maeda (who's Japanese, but happened to be touring around Europe at that time), who did this really amazing front-end for Clojure:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuU0HI-paik

Within the same space, there's Ella Hoeppner's Vlojure for ClojureScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OcAUhe3E1E

Katie Bell did a sort of similar work for Python that can be found at splootcode.io

@o_kryvonos living in Ukraine under russian fire managed to deliver Lisperanto:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QNyuMK8ZrHI

Among Ukrainian hackers, there's also Ivan Daniluk, who has some very interesting thoughts concerning "visual programming": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ps3mBPcjySE

And of course there's @jonathoda who - in addition to doing crazy experiments with his SubText (e.g. https://vimeo.com/451278506) has been doing wonderful stuff in bringing the community together with various workshops and other social initiatives.

Also, a lot of cool ideas can be found on "Emil's Programming Viz" vlog:

https://www.youtube.com/@emilsprogrammingviz1811

When it comes to visual thinking about computation, the ideas of @spiralganglion on the Hest programming environment are really outstanding, as is his conduction of the "Future of Coding" podcast (and taking @jimmyhmiller on board was certainly a great idea).

Yair Chuchem (and others) also did impressive work with the Lambdu programming environment, and Yair himself created this wonderful list of "awesome structure editors":
https://github.com/yairchu/awesome-structure-editors

If you feel that this list is incomplete or that your project (or some other important project) is missing from here, it's perhaps also because 2500 characters on this mastodon instance aren't all that much, but of course feel free to add replies to this toot.

https://www.youtube.com/@emilsprogrammingviz1811

When it comes to visual thinking about computation, the ideas of @spiralganglion on the Hest programming environment are really outstanding, as is his conduction of the "Future of Coding" podcast (and taking @jimmyhmiller on board was certainly a great idea).

Yair Chuchem (and others) also did impressive work with the Lambdu programming environment, and Yair himself created this wonderful list of "awesome structure editors":
https://github.com/yairchu/awesome-structure-editors

If you feel that this list is incomplete or that your project (or some other important project) is missing from here, it's perhaps also because 2500 characters on this mastodon instance aren't all that much, but of course feel free to add replies to this toot.

Recent announcement of Project Mage inspired me to write a short tour around the current scene of #StructuralEditing - from my perspective, so I shall begin with the projects that resonate with me most strongly.

So, the number 1 is @leif 's work on "Interactive Visual Syntax", as explained here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8htgAxJuK5c

(Leif also implemented this idea in the visr.pl online IDE)

Number 2 is @vez 's Polytope editor for JavaScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8g_XCZSY7lM

I was also hugely impressed with @disconcision 's Fructure, which - except just being a beautiful user experience also is a beautiful implementation:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnbVCNIh1NA

Andy has since moved to other places, contributing to Cyrus Omar's hazel.org and David Moon's tylr.fun

Not long after releasing my first prototype of GRASP, I ran into Yasuyuki Maeda (who's Japanese, but happened to be touring around Europe at that time), who did this really amazing front-end for Clojure:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuU0HI-paik

Within the same space, there's Ella Hoeppner's Vlojure for ClojureScript:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OcAUhe3E1E

Katie Bell did a sort of similar work for Python that can be found at splootcode.io

@o_kryvonos living in Ukraine under russian fire managed to deliver Lisperanto:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QNyuMK8ZrHI

Among Ukrainian hackers, there's also Ivan Daniluk, who has some very interesting thoughts concerning "visual programming": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ps3mBPcjySE

And of course there's @jonathoda who - in addition to doing crazy experiments with his SubText (e.g. https://vimeo.com/451278506) has been doing wonderful stuff in bringing the community together with various workshops and other social initiatives.

Also, a lot of cool ideas can be found on "Emil's Programming Viz" vlog:

https://www.youtube.com/@emilsprogrammingviz1811

When it comes to visual thinking about computation, the ideas of @spiralganglion on the Hest programming environment are really outstanding, as is his conduction of the "Future of Coding" podcast (and taking @jimmyhmiller on board was certainly a great idea).

Yair Chuchem (and others) also did impressive work with the Lambdu programming environment, and Yair himself created this wonderful list of "awesome structure editors":

title: Comparison of methods for the calculation of the real dilogarithm regarding instruction-level parallelism

last_post.content: If anyone ever needs to compute the integral of softplus (2-fold integral of sigmoid), it's -Li_2(-exp(x)) where Li_2 is the dilogarithm, and you can find a very good and fast numerical approximation to the dilogarithm of real argument in https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.01678.

title:
Behind this bench stood the magnificent neo-gothic red brick
building of St Paul's School from 1884 to 1968.
Celebrated Architect: Alfred Waterhouse
Boys were evacuated in WW2 and it became the HQ for 21st Army Group
commanded by former pupil General Montgomery.
The final decision to invade Normandy was taken here on 15th May 1944,
about which President Eisenhower wrote:
"During the whole of the war I attended no other
conference so packed with rank as this one."
King George VI, Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Generals Montgomery
and Eisenhower were amongst 146 present in the Lecture Theatre.
Bench presented by the Old Pauline Trust Ltd
to commemorate the 75th Anniversary of D-Day on 6th June 2019.

title: Development of an Offline-Friend Addiction Questionnaire (O-FAQ): Are most people really social addicts? - Behavior Research Methods

"Readers should approach our measure with a level of skepticism that should be afforded to current social media addiction measures."

To passively collect air pollution over time, I've been thinking about speed-modding a cassette player into a "videocamera" for dust.

For ex, I could cut an aperture in the side of the case, add sticky tape reels instead of a cassette, and speed-mod the servos to make it very slow.

So, Ω₄(n) is diffeomorphic to the space of quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ ⊕ {0} → {0} ⊕ℍⁱ, or simply quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ → ℍⁱ. Quaternion-unitary maps are the obvious generalization of unitary maps from ℂ to ℍ. The quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ → ℍⁱ form a compact Lie group called the 'quaternionic unitary group' or 'compact symplectic group' Sp(i):

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/compact+symplectic+group
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symplectic_group#Sp(n)

So, Ω₄(n) is diffeomorphic to this group!

(13/n)
